text: Organize your tent so that it's easy to grab things throughout the week.

subitems.text: For me, it is all about organization. If I can put everything away easily, I will find it easily.
Your tent will feel a lot bigger if you can keep it organized.
Make everything easy to find by throwing undies & socks in ziplocks. Hell, throw nearly everything in giant ziplocks.
You can also group like items in Ziplocs: socks in one, underwear in another, hair stuff in a third, etc. That makes it easier to find stuff than rooting through a ton of dusty bins.
Plastic Drawers Can be very handy for keeping your tent organized.
Crunchy suggests getting a 3-drawer bin from Big-Lots as your 'bedside table.'

text: Buy additional extra-long rebar (even if your tent came with stakes)

subitems.text: Do not use the tent stakes that came with your tent. The wind will pull them out and send your tent flying. Get extra long, heavy duty metal ones. The best solution is to use reinforcing bar or rebar, for short. If you can find some with the bend at the top, or have some bent like a candy cane, that’s even better. Note: You will probably need to bring/borrow a sledge hammer to drive the rebar into the playa, and vise grips to pull them out. And something to put over tops so that people don’t trip on them and gouge there ankle, like tennis balls with slits cut in them. Oh yeah, bring work gloves, too.

Get rebars to hold your tent down. The 1/3" stakes that you got with your REI tent isn't going to do anything to hold your tent down in 60mph winds. So, use rebars instead of stakes and use tennis balls or bottles to top them off to prevent others from hurting themselves on the sharp corners in the middle of the night.
Yes! But like always at Burning Man specifically, use rebar! Not the stakes that come with the tent.

Extra-long tent stakes. As I said above, the wind is no joke in the Black Rock Desert. I have seen 60mph gusts at Burning Man and I’ve also seen tents cartwheeling down the Playa like tumbleweeds. No fun…so when setting up your tent you need to batten down the hatches and expect the worst. Sometimes for larger tents it’s a good idea to bring super skinny rebar, which can be bent and driven down deep into the Playa to hold your tent in place.

If you are going to be setting up a tent, have a look at the stakes that came with it. These are usually small and made of lightweight aluminum or plastic, designed for backpacking, trading off strength for weight. Since you probably won’t be carrying the load on your back, go out and buy a few of those foot-long plastic or metal stakes they sell for larger tents. Also, for the same price, you can use
rebar stakes, a much better idea, described below.

If you are going to be using the small stakes that came with the tent, at least be sure to keep something large and heavy in your tent when you’re not there, like a loaded ice chest. You don’t want to be searching for your tent 20 miles downwind.

text: All camping tents should be a shade structure. Be sure to buy one.

subitems.text: You will need shade. The only part missing is the shade, which is why we also borrowed a legendary Burning Man shelter, the Costco car canopy: Put this tent up, then put the canopy over it. You get extra dust protection and plenty of shade. Air circulates between the canopy and the tent, so you can basically sleep in the middle of the day.

The direct sunlight heats up tents. This makes sleeping late in a tent problematic without some shade or other rigging." "Some people put their tents inside their shade structures to keep the tent cooler, but regardless, the lack of a shade structure—the lack of a sense of place—can make little things like food prep, eating, and cleanup that much less pleasant. The lack of daytime shade apart from one's tent (which will generally be too hot) means you may not be able hang out in your own camp when you want to and need to go somewhere else.

If you want to sleep, your tent needs to be in the shade. You can use a tarp or two and figure out a way to tie it from your car or a friends RV to go over your tent. I really don’t know how to do that kind of thing but THIS makes it look easy. I have only used pre-made shade like an EZup. If you use an EZup or other square shaped screen room, be extra careful to reinforce the stake down and guylines. Dust storms love to toss these around.
Shade structure! Get creative…it is essential to have some escape from the sun

text: Avoid tents with lots of mesh, or cover it.

subitems.text: The key is to make sure that any mesh openings in your tent also have a solid material flap that zippers over them.
There's so much mesh, that it breathed amazingly well. I thought it'd be the perfect tent for the hot desert. I was an idiot.
The one issue, though, was sand blown in... a tent with zip-up panels for the mesh would be better for the desert.
These tents usually have mesh in the walls...however is pretty useless to protect against sandstorms.
